title: Angular Lifecycle Hooks
subject: Angular
theory: A component has a lifecycle managed by Angular. Angular creates it, renders it, creates and renders its children, checks it when data bound properties change, and destroys it before removing it from the DOM. Hooks allow you to tap into these moments.

examples.explanation: ngOnInit is the most common place to fetch data.

common_mistakes.correction: The constructor is for simple initialization (like DI). Heavy logic should go in ngOnInit.

interview_questions.question: What is the difference between constructor and ngOnInit?
interview_questions.answer: Constructor is a TS feature for class instantiation. ngOnInit is an Angular lifecycle method called after Angular has finished setting up the component's data-bound input properties.

real_world_use_cases.description: Unsubscribing from Observables in ngOnDestroy to prevent memory leaks.

exam_notes: Order: OnChanges -> OnInit -> DoCheck -> AfterContent -> AfterView -> OnDestroy.
summary: Lifecycle hooks provide precise control over how components behave throughout their existence.
